title: Ticket #3367: Condor thinks VMs in OpenStack's "SHUTOFF" state are running
description:
OpenStack has VM states in addition to the Amazon EC2 states. One of them is a "SHUTOFF" state. The VMs are still in the system and can be restarted, but they are not running. Condor thinks VMs in this state are running when in reality they are not (condor_q reports them running).

Per Jaime: Should be easy to fix. The tricky part is what should Condor do? Two options spring to mind:

1) Consider the job complete, destroy the instance, and let the job leave the queue.

2) Mark the job as Idle with GridJobStatus set to SHUTOFF and let the user set PeriodicRemove to destroy the instance if they want to.

For my use case in glideinWMS I'd choose 1), however, I could see where 2) would be preferable.
remarks:
After discussion on 2013-01-11 (between JaimeF, TonyT, ToddT, and ToddM), we will immediately implement option (1), above, perhaps to be followed by representing a job in the SHUTOFF states with the Condor 'suspended' state, provided we can rejigger condor_resume to the do the right thing.

2013-Jan-15 15:40:17 by tlmiller:
Interestingly enough, OpenStack uses the same InstanceStateType code (number), 48, for 'shutoff' that Amazon uses for 'terminated'. This will probably not end up mattering...

2013-Jan-16 13:38:05 by tlmiller:
Tested by setting EC2_VM_STATE_SHUTOFF to 'running'. The state transitions happened properly, and the job status looks OK in condor_history.

I've asked Tony Tiradani if he can help test this patch. I have access to an OpenStack Essex service (FutureGrid), but I don't know how to generate SHUTOFF instances.
